comment.body:
About *Mobile applications*, Android is a lot more open then any other mobile OS. Per example, I use [F-Droid](https://f-droid.org) and am not connected at all to any Google applications. (which means no Google Play access and no Google Play Services). F-Droid only features open-source applications and shows warnings when an application uses proprietary software.

I think it might be nice to have a ZeroNet SDK installable, providing an API for applications to use ZeroNet (with a certain way to allow some applications to use certain user certs). Then we would only have to store zites once on the device.

Seeding is also a problem on mobile. Low-end WiFi chipsets tend to restart often (which breaks any connections) when under high usage. On mobile data, seeding can't even be thought of. Push notifications is a good idea, but need a central server (*I think*).

Just a non-related question -- for when ZeroNet x IPFS for large files ?
